com.noctarius.borabora

Interface Output

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    CompositeBuffer

    public interface Output
    An Output instance represents a target sink for writeable data. Output implementations are considered to neither be stateless not thread-safe as data is stored which is a non side-effect free situation. Whereas most implementations don't necessarily need to use the provided offset which is passed to write methods, it can be used to prevent storing internal offsets. As all writes coming from the generators are in order and immediate, the offset is constantly increasing only and does not need random pokes.

    A common basic example for the usage of Output looks like:

         Output output = Output.toCompositeBuffer( ... );
     Writer writer = Writer.newBuilder().build();
     GraphBuilder graphBuilder = writer.newGraphBuilder( output );
     // generate the actual data stream
    See Also:
    GraphBuilder, Writer, CompositeBuffer

    • Method Detail

      • write

        long write(long offset,
           byte value)
        Writes a single byte to the given offset and the underlying sink. If the offset is outside the writable area a NoSuchByteException is thrown. Otherwise the byte is written and the new offset is returned.
        Parameters:
        offset - the offset to write to
        value - the value to write
        Returns:
        the new offset after writing

      • write

        long write(byte[] array,
           long offset,
           int length)
        Writes zero or more bytes defined by the given length. Data is written from the given byte-array (bytes) and writing starts from the provided offset. If offset or offset plus length results in an offset larger than the writable area, or length is larger then the given byte-array's length, a NoSuchByteException is thrown.
        Parameters:
        array - the byte-array to write
        offset - the offset to write to
        length - the number of bytes to write
        Returns:
        the new offset after writing

      • toCompositeBuffer

        static Output toCompositeBuffer(CompositeBuffer compositeBuffer)
        Returns an Output instance backed by the provided compositeBuffer. The CompositeBuffer is implemented as a linked list of byte-array's called chunks. The buffer is automatically growing and prevents recreation and copying of internal byte-arrays. This makes it fast for writing, however the single linked list design makes random access read access slow. That said, a CompositeBuffer is good for writing if the resulting stream size is unknown but should only be used for reading in rare cases.
        Parameters:
        compositeBuffer - the CompositeBuffer to write to
        Returns:
        the new output instance backed by the given compositeBuffer
        See Also:
        CompositeBuffer

      • toByteArray

        static Output toByteArray(byte[] bytes)
        Returns an Output instance backed by the provided bytes byte-array. The instance returned does not handle offsets larger than Integer.MAX_VALUE due to the limitation of Java. All offsets larger will result in an IllegalArgumentException being thrown.
        Parameters:
        bytes - the byte-array to be used as the backing storage for the new out instance
        Returns:
        the new output instance backed by the given byte-array

      • toNative

        static Output toNative(long address,
                       long size)
        Returns an Output instance backed by the provided address which represents a native memory address and the given size for the number of available bytes. The instance returned is implemented using Unsafe to provide native memory access and to provide 64 bit offsets. Not all JVMs support this kind of access and therefore it might fail to be used.
        Parameters:
        address - the native memory address of the data
        size - the number of bytes of the writable data
        Returns:
        the new output instance backed by the given address and size

      • toOutputStream

        static Output toOutputStream(OutputStream out)
        Returns an Output instance backed by the provided out OutputStream instance. The instance returned does not handle offsets larger than Integer.MAX_VALUE due to the limitation of the Java API. All offsets larger will result in an IllegalArgumentException being thrown.
        Parameters:
        out - the output stream instance to write to
        Returns:
        the new output instance backed by the given output stream
